## 'Speedy' Intro

::: {style="font-size: 28pt"}
-   Ocean warming as a driver for shifts in species' habitats

<br>

-   North Pacific Ocean is changing: considerable documentation of pelagic animals response to anomalous conditions & established expansion of subtropical gyre [(Polovina et al. 2011)]{style="font-size: 22pt"}

<br>

-   Most studies: short-term or simulations... but we have a unique data set <br> (+2 decades) to explore these changes
:::

## Questions {.scrollable}

1.  How do Sept turtle-18°C SST positions compare between historic (1997-2012) and 2023 turtles in the NE Pacific? Is this a northward expansion of habitat?

<br>

2.  2023 was an unprecedented year. Are turtles responding to year-to-year variability or longer-term trends in ocean warming? <br>

          [Given that H<sub>0</sub>: there is no change in seasonal bounds of subtropical gyre & turtle habitat]{style="font-size: 24pt"} <br>                 -- [H<sub>1</sub>: Year to year variability but no long-term trend in seasonal bounds of gyre & turtle habitat]{style="font-size: 24pt"} <br>                 -- [H<sub>2</sub>: Expansion of summer bounds (ie Sept) due to rapid warming]{style="font-size: 24pt"} <br>                 -- [H<sub>3</sub>: Expansion of summer and winter bounds (ie Sept and Mar)]{style="font-size: 24pt"} <br>

## Results {.scrollable}

<div style='font-size: 26pt'>

-   Historically \~18C°SST and loggerhead forage habitat moves seasonally from about <br> **30°N lat in March to about 40°N lat** in September

<br>

-   Tagging release in [**2023**]{style="color:#447099"} NE Pacific showed loggerheads still tracking 18°C SST but <br> [**reaching several degrees further north (45°N)**]{style="color:#447099"} than historic data set

<br>

::: fragment
-   Analysis of 18°C SST location (1985 - 2023) shows [**March and Sept seasonal bounds** <br> **moving north over time**]{style="color:#76B7B2"} with loggerheads also moving northward, tracking 18C SST

<br>

-   Implications of northerly shift of 18°C SST means implications include need to <br> [**travel farther to reach productive TZCF**]{style="color:#76B7B2"} and consequentially foraging/developmental grounds... What will this mean for subsequent travel timing/distance to coastal habitat?

<br>

-   As a sentinel species, how could this shift could inform us about larger [**ecosystem shifts**]{style="color:#76B7B2"} and species responses?

</div>
:::
